description: The Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) certification is the gold standard in the IT Security field. Security professionals that have achieved their CISSP designation are regarded as some of the most talented and knowledgeable people in their field. The certification demonstrates that the holder has been working in IT Security for over five years, has a broad range of knowledge in ten domains related to creating, supporting and maintaining a secure IT infrastructure and can implement things like risk management and risk identification.

00:10:20.880 --> 00:10:23.170
You may be visual, you may see things.

188
00:10:23.170 --> 00:10:26.270
People that have photographic
memories fall into this category.

189
00:10:26.270 --> 00:10:27.472
I hate those people by the way.

190
00:10:27.472 --> 00:10:29.958
[LAUGH] I cannot stand them,
I struggle with that.

191
00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.387
I've been an educator and
a teacher for over 30,

192
00:10:32.387 --> 00:10:37.065
close to 35 years I learn as
a kinesthetic learner, primarily.

193
00:10:37.065 --> 00:10:41.655
I'm somebody who has to do things and
interact and sample them and tear them

194
00:10:41.655 --> 00:10:44.455
out, put them back together, really
make it my own and claim that knowledge.

195
00:10:44.455 --> 00:10:46.185
That's why I share it with you over time.

196
00:10:46.185 --> 00:10:47.135
But when I do flashcards,

197
00:10:47.135 --> 00:10:49.905
I still hand write them,
because that's how I learn best.

198
00:10:49.905 --> 00:10:51.705
I know that about myself.

199
00:10:51.705 --> 00:10:56.690
And, as an educator First and foremost,
I have to be aware of the fact that not

200
00:10:56.690 --> 00:11:00.160
everybody in my classroom is a student,
is gonna learn the way I learn.

201
00:11:00.160 --> 00:11:02.890
And therefore I can't teach just one way.

202
00:11:02.890 --> 00:11:06.020
Because if I all do is teach
in a kinesthetic approach,

203
00:11:06.020 --> 00:11:08.070
I'm gonna be in the sweet spot for
people like me.

204
00:11:08.070 --> 00:11:11.120

off camera agreeing with me when I said,

205
00:11:11.120 --> 00:11:12.740
that's the kind of learner I am.

206
00:11:12.740 --> 00:11:15.480
That it would be great for
us, but it may not work for

207
00:11:15.480 --> 00:11:17.760
you, cuz maybe you don't learn that way.

208
00:11:17.760 --> 00:11:20.870
And as a result,
I got to constantly be aware of that and

209
00:11:20.870 --> 00:11:24.540
I got to be incorporating multiple
approaches and techniques to be able to

210
00:11:24.540 --> 00:11:29.230
allow people that are learning different
modalities or from different perspectives.

211
00:11:29.230 --> 00:11:31.950
And it's important for
us to be aware of that and

212
00:11:31.950 --> 00:11:36.370
think about that as we evaluate
effectiveness, because not everybody finds

213
00:11:36.370 --> 00:11:40.048
an approach that works for
that person to be effective for them.

214
00:11:40.048 --> 00:11:41.983
We have to be sensitive to that.

215
00:11:41.983 --> 00:11:45.717
We wanna reach saturation in coverage
where everybody is gonna be able to

216
00:11:45.717 --> 00:11:49.942
operate or be involved in the culture of
security we wanna create because they're

217
00:11:49.942 --> 00:11:52.455
incorporated into and
are drawing value from and

218
00:11:52.455 --> 00:11:56.840
obviously this is all acting accordingly
the messages we are communicating out.

219
00:11:56.840 --> 00:11:58.220
So keep that in mind,

220
00:11:58.220 --> 00:12:02.370
right, this monolithic approach
to delivery of information.

221
00:12:02.370 --> 00:12:07.280
That comes from just one modality,
this is unfortunately the standard and

222
00:12:07.280 --> 00:12:10.160
norm in many organizations but
is not the best approach.

223
00:12:10.160 --> 00:12:15.160
And we have to as CISSPs constantly
be fighting those battles

224
00:12:15.160 --> 00:12:19.060
to ensure that we are delivering as much
value to the organization as we can.

225
00:12:19.060 --> 00:12:21.807
This is an area where we can have
an effect, and it's a small area, and

226
00:12:21.807 --> 00:12:24.540
often people often overlook the value and
importance of it.

227
00:12:24.540 --> 00:12:28.442
Remember, building awareness is
the same thing as building culture.

228
00:12:28.442 --> 00:12:32.352
And we build the culture of security
because that's the foundation

229
00:12:32.352 --> 00:12:36.740
that everything else rests on, and
enables everything else we talk about,

230
00:12:36.740 --> 00:12:40.308
throughout all the domains,
across all areas of knowledge,

231
00:12:40.308 --> 00:12:44.120
in every aspect of the practice
that a CISSP has to engage.

232
00:12:44.120 --> 00:12:47.699
Very, very important.
>> Well, very important stuff.

It's a very important process.

Something we should be doing, and

now you should be able to explain to the
people that you are administering this to,

00:13:04.890 --> 00:13:07.080

Great stuff, Adam,

Root cause,

00:00:52.090 --> 00:00:57.321
We are having our conversations around

24
00:00:57.321 --> 00:01:02.098

00:01:02.098 --> 00:01:06.303
and/or data as an example of
the asset class and category.

26
00:01:06.303 --> 00:01:11.373
But remember, it is simply one type of
asset and assets all up overall would be

00:01:11.373 --> 00:01:16.366
the broader context that we talk about
all things that the organization owns

28
00:01:16.366 --> 00:01:21.540
that is somehow going to have value
and/or important to subscribe to it.

29
00:01:21.540 --> 00:01:22.790
So keep that in mind.

30
00:01:22.790 --> 00:01:26.784
Also, we talked about the concept
of data ownership, and

31
00:01:26.784 --> 00:01:32.327
the idea that whoever the individual or
entity is that owns the data in question,

32
00:01:32.327 --> 00:01:36.503
as the asset should determine
classification of that data.

33

34

quarterly, whatever review life cycle
time we assign to be involved in that

35
00:01:45.791 --> 00:01:50.399
review to assess whether classification
is still appropriate or perhaps,

36
00:01:50.399 --> 00:01:54.720
data must be reclassified under
some sort of additional scheme.

37
00:01:54.720 --> 00:01:59.159
So join me here, we're gonna take on our
second topic in the asset security domain,

38
00:01:59.159 --> 00:02:02.425
permanently maintaining information and
asset ownership.

39
00:02:02.425 --> 00:02:05.454
Ownership as we said,
is very critical, very important,

40
00:02:05.454 --> 00:02:08.068
because among the many
things ownership implies.

41
00:02:08.068 --> 00:02:12.619
It implies the ability, in the case

42
00:02:12.619 --> 00:02:16.873

remember classification implies that we

43
00:02:16.873 --> 00:02:21.070
are setting up some sort of scheme,
some sort of way to label data.

44
00:02:21.070 --> 00:02:23.530
We said there's a variety
of things we could do.

45
00:02:23.530 --> 00:02:28.551
But whatever that scheme is, whatever
that labeling will be, that will be

46
00:02:28.551 --> 00:02:33.907
used to drive access to the data based on
whatever requirements we put in place.

47
00:02:33.907 --> 00:02:39.015
So a top secret labeling or top secret
classification would be different

48
00:02:39.015 --> 00:02:44.472
than a secret and eyes only, all the other
examples we could throw out there.

49
00:02:44.472 --> 00:02:47.572
And each one of those
classification labels and

50
00:02:47.572 --> 00:02:52.689
layers would then have access controls and
requirements associated with it,

51
00:02:52.689 --> 00:02:58.228
again, they have to be defined,
documented, implemented, audited, etc.

52
00:02:58.228 --> 00:03:00.890
But they will have those
associated with them,

53
00:03:00.890 --> 00:03:05.280
then they drive access to the data,
access to the asset.

54
00:03:05.280 --> 00:03:10.020
And indeed, in order to ensure
confidentiality in the case of data

55
00:03:10.020 --> 00:03:14.450
integrity, in the case of data and
certain availability in the case of data.

56
00:03:14.450 --> 00:03:17.919
But also keep in mind, so
I made the point in the last episode.

57
00:03:17.919 --> 00:03:21.945
It's not just data and I just made
point again, started this conversation.

58
00:03:21.945 --> 00:03:26.360
Data is one kind of asset, but
broadly, there are multiple types,

59
00:03:26.360 --> 00:03:29.570
or categories of assets
in the organization.

60
00:03:29.570 --> 00:03:32.350
Systems overall are assets.

61
00:03:32.350 --> 00:03:34.860
I made this case in the last episode
where I talked about military and

62
00:03:34.860 --> 00:03:40.790
government installations where entire
rooms, entire areas, whole buildings and

63
00:03:40.790 --> 00:03:47.090
facilities are classified according to
access levels as are computer systems.

64
00:03:47.090 --> 00:03:49.930
It's funny the first few times you go into
one of these places, especially if you

65
00:03:49.930 --> 00:03:54.160
have not had this experience, and
if you are from the military or

66
00:03:54.160 --> 00:03:57.660
the government or have a background in
working as a consultant in these areas,

67
00:03:57.660 --> 00:04:00.770
you will certainly appreciate to know
what I'm about to share with you.

68
00:04:00.770 --> 00:04:05.110
But everything is labeled, and so you have
red labels and you have green labels.

69
00:04:06.160 --> 00:04:09.540
Red labeling is for classified systems,

70
00:04:09.540 --> 00:04:14.190
secret systems that have access
constriction or controls assigned to them.

71
00:04:14.190 --> 00:04:18.999
And green labels are for non-classified
systems, open access kind of thing,

72
00:04:18.999 --> 00:04:20.086
which is normal.

73
00:04:20.086 --> 00:04:24.500
You see in monitors or in computers,
they have red or green labels on them.

74
00:04:24.500 --> 00:04:28.090
You see signs on doors or
meeting rooms, that kind of thing.

75
00:04:28.090 --> 00:04:31.140
That's all fine, but
down to the mouse pad, right.

76
00:04:31.140 --> 00:04:34.019
So literally,
you don't see mouse pads much anymore,

77
00:04:34.019 --> 00:04:36.417
it's just kind of this
an older kind of thing.

78
00:04:36.417 --> 00:04:39.620
We had mice that were not
able to track on surfaces.

79
00:04:39.620 --> 00:04:42.640
But when you had roller ball mice,
as opposed to optical mice,

80
00:04:42.640 --> 00:04:43.900
you had mouse pads.

81
00:04:43.900 --> 00:04:46.070
And you would walk into these systems,
literally,

82
00:04:46.070 --> 00:04:48.975
you would turn the mouse pad and
it would have a confidential,

83
00:04:48.975 --> 00:04:54.760
non-confidential green or red sticker on
it because it was part of the totality

84
00:04:54.760 --> 00:04:59.070
of the architecture of the system, and
as a result it had to be classified.

85
00:04:59.070 --> 00:05:02.230
It was nothing secret or
classified about the mouse pad, but

86
00:05:02.230 --> 00:05:04.560
it was part of a classified system.

87
00:05:04.560 --> 00:05:06.708
So you would get these crazy things where-
>> That's funny.

88
00:05:06.708 --> 00:05:08.929
>> I walked into an office and literally,

00:05:08.929 --> 00:05:13.187

00:05:13.187 --> 00:05:13.770
>> [LAUGH]

00:05:13.770 --> 00:05:15.115
>> They obviously were bored and

had nothing to do, right?

00:05:17.673 --> 00:05:20.302
out the ceiling [CROSSTALK].

00:05:20.302 --> 00:05:21.942
are bored and have nothing to do, right?

95
00:05:21.942 --> 00:05:23.720
It's stickers and time on their hands.

96
00:05:23.720 --> 00:05:26.840
Every pencil had a red classified label,
and

97
00:05:26.840 --> 00:05:30.610
then there was another cup holder where
all the pencils were green, right?

98
00:05:30.610 --> 00:05:32.945
And it wasn't because one was secret and
not, it was [CROSSTALK]

99
00:05:32.945 --> 00:05:33.867
>> It was a supply chain attack they

100
00:05:33.867 --> 00:05:35.821
were trying to avoid [CROSSTALK]
>> They were trying to confuse and

101
00:05:35.821 --> 00:05:36.851
confound the enemy, right?

102
00:05:36.851 --> 00:05:38.920
But it was just funny,
I mean, just look at it.

103
00:05:38.920 --> 00:05:40.890
You see the irony in that stuff.

104
00:05:40.890 --> 00:05:45.585
But it is, it speaks to a broader issue,
which is we have to be aware of the fact

105
00:05:45.585 --> 00:05:49.656
that all assets, right potentially
can be classified as we said.

106
00:05:49.656 --> 00:05:52.479
We tend to see this
primarily around data but

00:05:52.479 --> 00:05:57.669
that's not an exclusive statement, I want
you to be clear on that and understand

108
00:05:57.669 --> 00:06:02.658
that that there are additional asset
classes that will often be classified.

109
00:06:02.658 --> 00:06:06.112
And as a result, have labeling
the controls so as you do with that,

110
00:06:06.112 --> 00:06:08.760
so please just keep that
in mind as we get started.

111
00:06:08.760 --> 00:06:10.720
All right, so join me here if you will.

112
00:06:10.720 --> 00:06:11.520
Let's take a look.

113
00:06:12.590 --> 00:06:14.910
Determining and maintaining information,
asset ownership.

114
00:06:14.910 --> 00:06:15.812
Very small conversation.

115
00:06:15.812 --> 00:06:18.192
This is one of those,
they should come up with a name.

116
00:06:18.192 --> 00:06:21.385
I'm thinking, like, micro episode,
cuz this is a pretty quick one.

117
00:06:21.385 --> 00:06:24.465
A data policy defines the goals for
data management.

118
00:06:24.465 --> 00:06:29.252
Well, we know from other conversations
earlier in other episodes,

119
00:06:29.252 --> 00:06:32.965
in the first domain,
security and risk management,

120
00:06:32.965 --> 00:06:36.608
where we defined policy,
standard, guidelines.

121
00:06:36.608 --> 00:06:40.635
We defined these terms, right,
in terms of vocabulary,

122
00:06:40.635 --> 00:06:46.220
that a policy is a statement of intent and
guidance from senior leadership.

123
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:50.080
In the organization,
it is seen as more of a strategic

124
00:06:50.080 --> 00:06:54.630
as opposed to a procedure more of
a tactical approach to things and

125
00:06:54.630 --> 00:07:00.045
answers to very important questions, why
are we doing this and what are we doing?

126
00:07:00.045 --> 00:07:04.140
Whereas, procedures
are step by step guidance

127
00:07:04.140 --> 00:07:08.380
that are provided to implement policy.

128
00:07:08.380 --> 00:07:12.470
And so policy, whatever words you
put in front of it doesn't matter.

129
00:07:12.470 --> 00:07:17.130
Retention policy, data policy,
access control policy,

130
00:07:17.130 --> 00:07:19.670
we've got policies for all sorts of stuff.

131
00:07:19.670 --> 00:07:21.587
Whatever the policy speaks to,

132
00:07:21.587 --> 00:07:26.344
the generic idea of policy is this high
level of strategic statement of guidance

133
00:07:26.344 --> 00:07:31.180
that helps us to apply due diligence from
the perspective of senior management.

134
00:07:31.180 --> 00:07:36.640
Procedures translate and implement
policy into tactical operational step

135
00:07:36.640 --> 00:07:42.266
by step things that could be executed
that give practitioners the ability to,

136
00:07:42.266 --> 00:07:47.460
with the guidance from policy,
exercise and operate with due care.

137
00:07:47.460 --> 00:07:51.980
Bringing those terms back in and linking
them for you yet again, cuz they are so

138
00:07:51.980 --> 00:07:52.900
important.

139
00:07:52.900 --> 00:07:57.820
So in this case, data policy provides and
defines the goals for data management.

140
00:07:57.820 --> 00:07:59.090
Okay, that makes sense.

141
00:07:59.090 --> 00:08:02.202
Why do we do data management,
and what does data management

142
00:08:02.202 --> 00:08:05.698
represent in the organization is
what a data policy will speak to.

143
00:08:05.698 --> 00:08:09.670
It helps to establish a guiding
